body.p: Although the IASB did not receive strong support for the proposals in the Supplementary Document, some respondents, particularly users of financial statements and prudential regulators, supported the distinction between ‘good book’ and ‘bad book’ assets even if they were concerned that the criteria for transferring from the ‘good book’ to the ‘bad book’ were not sufficiently clear. On balance, the IASB decided not to further pursue this two-tier approach.
